The type of host key algorithm in use.

SSHv2(OpenSSH Portable) host public key component encoded in PEM format:
<key type><SPACE>...base64 encoded OpenSSH public key....<SPACE><comment>
Container of management protocol objects.
Control of ssh access.
Enables direct access to shell via ssh.
Port listening for ssh login that goes directly to shell.
Welcome message displayed before user login.

default.@value:
****************************************** Warning ******************************************

This system is restricted to authorized users for business purposes. Unauthorized access is a
violation of the law. This service may be monitored for administrative and security reasons.
By proceeding, you consent to this monitoring.

description.text: Welcome message displayed after user login.

Global(for server and client side SSHv2 based apps) SSHv2 host keys.
  There needs to be one host key per supported algorithm.
  The system auto-generates a host-key in default DB and
  additional host-keys can be added/overwritten via the ssh-keygen RPC.
The type of hash algorithm in use for computing the key fingerprint

Fingerprint string as a sequence of pairs of hex digits.
SSHv2 public key fingerprint examples for MD5 and SHA256 hash:
md5sum fingerprint => b2:9c:cd:30:b1:38:e3:d1:17:d6:73:eb:03:9a:80:83
sha256sum fingerprint => f4:61:58:e4:90:65:c4:70:98:7f:d1:40:0a:d8:d9:79:14:e6:91:dc:b6:ed:91:8c:c0:df:d9:65:db:dd:a0:18
SSHv2 known hosts entry.
A unique identifier (name) for this entry.
The hostname/IPv4/IPv6 address of the allowed/known peer host.

SSHv2 authorized key.
Each authorized key entry contains a trusted public key for SSHv2 user authentication.
User owning the authorized key. Can be local or remote user.
A unique identifier (name) for this entry.
The type of key algorithm used. Auto-discovered based on provided public key.
Base64-encoded OpenSSH public key.
Configuration of the Command Line Interface (CLI) management protocol.
Enables/disables the CLI management protocol.
The port which listens for CLI access via ssh.
Location in the filesystem where CLI scripts are stored.

Defines whether CLI sessions have interactive-mode enabled or disabled by default.
Individual sessions can deviate from this global flag by configuring the interactive-mode at the cli-session-config level.
Note: changing this parameter will not affect existing CLI sessions, only newly created sessions.

List of aliases used in CLI.
Can only be accessed via 'alias/unalias' CLI commands.
Name of the alias
Value of the alias
Configurations associated with individual CLI sessions.
The identifier of the CLI session

Number of rows to be used for display. This value is automatically
discovered when possible

Number of columns to be used for display. This value is automatically
discovered when possible

This determines if the CLI shall issue interactive prompt (e.g. for prompting
additional information, or for confirmation of user initiated actions).
Enabled = CLI will prompt user (default)
This determines if the current timestamp will be printed on every CLI command.
Global configuration of all serial console ports in the system.
Allow access by serial-console. Note: each console port can override this global behavior.
Serial console inactivity timeout. Can be set to zero to disable inactivity timer.
Configuration of the NETCONF management protocol.
Enables/disables the NETCONF management protocol.
The port which listens for NETCONF access via ssh.
If enabled, annotates NETCONF XML output with cli names for traceability.

Specifies the number of seconds that a session may exist
before the hello PDU is received/transmitted.  A session will be
dropped if no hello PDU is received/transmitted before this number
of seconds elapses.
TL1 protocol configuration
Decides whether TL1 protocol is accessible over SSH or not.
SSH port that gives access to interactive interface of TL1 protocol server.
SSH port that gives access to non-interactive or scripting interface of TL1 protocol server. This interface does not echo terminal characters to client.
Configuration of the RESTCONF management protocol.
User configurable switch to enable or disable RESTCONF access.
User configurable switch to enable or disable RESTCONF HTTP access.
User configurable switch to enable or disable RESTCONF HTTPS access.
User configurable RESTCONF HTTP port.
User configurable RESTCONF HTTPS port.
Timeout of a cookie based RESTCONF session.
Root of the RESTCONF API.
Configuration of both gNMI & gNOI /gRPC management protocol.
Enables/disables the gRPC management protocol.
The port which listens for gNMI & gNOI access via gRPC.
Put all path data on a Update message.
Divide the path data into multiple Update messages, one per YANG container/list entry.
Allows to configure the granularity of data in gNMI Get responses, when encoded with JSON.
Configuration of the SNMP management protocol.
User configurable switch to enable or disable global SNMP access.
User configurable port where the NE is listening for SNMP requests.

SNMP EngineID of the NE.
The EngineID will follow the EngineID format 3 defined in RFC3411.
The MAC address in the Engine ID will be the first MAC address of the MAC addresses Pool of the NE.

SNMP engine boot count.
Counts how many times the engine has restarted.

List of SNMP Community Strings.
Note: trap-community-string is located in the snmp-target object.
Name for the community (different from the community string itself).
Community String.
User configurable switch to enable or disable this community-string.
SNMP access right of this community string.
List of SNMP targets (trap listeners)

SNMPv3 user configuration.
SNMPv3 user name.

Specifies the SNMPv3 user security level.
Note: when NE is in secure-mode, only auth-priv is allowed.
Specifies the authentication protocol that the SNMPv3 user being created will use.
Specifies the SNMPv3 authentication pass phrase.
Specifies the privacy protocol that the SNMPv3 user being created will use.
Specifies the SNMPv3 privacy pass phrase.
HTTP file server configuration
User configurable switch to enable or disable file server access.
User configurable switch to enable or disable HTTP protocol for file server access.
User configurable switch to enable or disable HTTPS protocol for file server access.
User configurable HTTP port.
User configurable HTTPS port.
The base URL use to redirect to the file transfer application.

Fast Telemetry provides an alternative telemetry channel that accesses the hardware directly for specific metrics.
         Please consult documentation to see what metrics are available per card type.
User configurable switch to enable or disable fast telemetry streaming.
gnmi openconfig streaming.
User configurable attribute to select the desired protocol.
User configurable port.
Information on supported NETCONF streams and notifications.
List of supported notifications.
Notification qualified name (prefix:name).
Notification namespace.
Description of the notification.
Indicates the scope of the notification - which data model it applies to.
List of supported NETCONF streams, their description and other information.
The name of the event stream.
Description of the event stream.
State of the stream (tied with the respective data-model enabled leaf).
Contains the list of supported notifications.
Dial-out-server name.
Dial-out-server IPv4/IPv6 address or hostname.
Dial-Out with gRPC Tunnels.
Dial-out-server session type.
Dial-out-server session port.
Dial-out-server transport protocol.
Try to reconnect with an exponentional time interval.
Retry a fixed number of times with a fixed timeout interval.
Retry forever with a fixed timeout interval.
Retry policy after a timeout.
Number of retries before giving up.
Wait time until timeout.
If true, automatically tries to connect to this dial-out-server. Note that a server with auto-connect false can still be connected manually via the call-home RPC.
Session is currently established with 'home'.
Running through the retries; also used if connected, and session abruptly is terminated.
All retries have failed, no further attempts are being done to connect to it.
session was established, and was gracefully closed.
Enabled parameter is false.
Connection state to the dial-out-server.
Available YANG Data models for loading/unloading.
Model name.
Data model description.
Allows to load/unload this data model.A loaded data model means that it can be used via the management interfaces.
Allows caching of config data for the given data-model.
Container of individual user-configurable scheduled commands.
User configurable scheduled task. Can define single occurrence or periodic commands.
Identifier of the scheduled task.
Enable switch of this task; allows user to disable a task without deleting it.
Command that is scheduled. Content will depend on the command-type.
CLI command.
Type of configured command.

Frequency interval for setting up a periodic scheduled task.
If empty (default value), represents a single-occurrence task.
Frequency interval is provided using the following syntax:
   '[xw] [xd] [xh] [xm] [xs]'
where:
    w(eeks), d(ays), h(ours), m(inutes), s(seconds).
Examples:
   2w          - two weeks
   5d 12h      - 5 days and 12 hours
   1h 7m 30s   - 1 hour and 7 minutes and 30 seconds

Timestamp to start the task. For periodic tasks, this is the timestamp for the first trigger of the task.
If not provided, uses current time as start-time.

Timestamp to stop the periodic task.
Not relevant for single-occurrence tasks.
If true, this scheduled task will persist a system restart.
Task is enabled and will run when the time comes.
Task is disabled by user.
Task has reached its end-time, or single occurrence task was already executed.
Task is enabled and is currently running
Current operational state of the scheduled task.
Next run timestamp. May be 'never' for finished tasks.
Previous task run timestamp.
Previous task run result.
Output of the previous task run.
